patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge when a contributor or maintainer comment states 'accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to roll this back' or 'accidentally merged this but it's problematic' with either an explicit revert commit SHA or a detailed critical bug enumeration, even if the original merge commit SHA is also present. The revert or 'problematic' statement is the terminal signal. Treat both explicit-revert-SHA and critical-bug-acknowledgment variants of accidental merge language as terminal non-merge signals per P-5-3. When an explicit revert SHA is present it is a stronger signal; when absent, critical bug enumeration by a trusted contributor combined with author bug acknowledgment is sufficient.

attributions.reason: CONTRIBUTOR (steipete) stated 'We accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to temporarily roll this back' with revert commit SHA 4fa35d3fd9f6a263f7586f18fbcc9f9b92b30744. Terminal non-merge signal per P-5-3 extended by P-6-6. The model predicted merge based on the merge SHA without recognizing the authoritative revert.

CONTRIBUTOR (steipete) stated 'We accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to temporarily roll this back' with both original merge SHA and revert SHA. Terminal non-merge signal per P-5-3 extended by new P-6-6. The model predicted merge based on the merge SHA presence without recognizing the authoritative batch-revert.

CONTRIBUTOR (steipete) stated 'We accidentally merged a batch of PRs and need to temporarily roll this back' with explicit revert SHA 563df5638bc8a6fd5cc5fb7c036844ce1f71d573 and follow-up 'Please re-open this in a new PR, needs far more time to review.' Terminal non-merge signal per P-5-3 and P-6-6. The model predicted non-merge but the accidental merge was counted as merge in ground truth; the revert is the authoritative terminal signal.

patterns.pattern: A member comment explicitly stating revert with named revert commits is a terminal non-merge signal overriding all positive indicators including prior merge events, even for small focused fixes.
patterns.evidence: PR #18063: MEMBER (shakkernerd) comment 'Reverting this PR because it was merged accidentally. Revert commits: - d8a76282d - dd69fc0ad'. S-sized fix (1 file), first-time contributor. The explicit revert with two named commits is authoritative. The model predicted merge (FN) — likely based on the prior accidental merge event — without recognizing the revert as terminal.
patterns.mechanism: An explicit member revert comment naming specific revert commits constitutes direct evidence that the merge was undone. The net repository state is non-merged. Multiple revert commits (two listed) further confirm the deliberateness of the rollback. This is consistent with P-5-3 but adds evidence that even small single-file fixes that were accidentally merged are subject to this pattern.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge when a member comment names specific revert commits for a PR that was merged accidentally, regardless of PR size, scope, or technical quality. The revert commit list is a terminal non-merge signal. Extends P-5-3 to member-role revert statements with multiple named revert commits.

attributions.reason: MEMBER (shakkernerd) explicitly stated 'Reverting this PR because it was merged accidentally' with two named revert commits. Terminal non-merge signal per P-5-3 and new P-6-7. The model predicted merge despite the explicit authoritative revert.

patterns.pattern: S-sized PRs from authors with 100% merge rate based on a single prior PR but with failing CI and no human reviewer comments or approvals do not reliably merge.
patterns.evidence: PR #18951: author with 1 prior PR at 100% merge rate, S-sized (4 files), focused scope, only automated greptile review, ci_green=false, zero comments, zero human reviews, no maintainer label. PR not merged despite perfect prior merge rate.
patterns.mechanism: A single prior merged PR establishes a 100% merge rate but provides minimal statistical confidence. Failing CI (ci_green=false) signals unresolved test failures. Without a human reviewer to confirm the fix is correct and CI failures are acceptable, the PR stalls. The combination of failing CI and zero human engagement leaves the PR in an unvalidated state regardless of prior merge rate.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge for S-sized PRs based on a 100% merge rate derived from a single prior PR when CI is failing and there are zero human reviewer comments or approvals. Failing CI combined with no human engagement is a non-merge signal that overrides a 100% rate from fewer than 3 prior PRs. See also P-5-6 for the analogous docs-only case.

attributions.reason: Author had 100% merge rate from single prior PR (insufficient statistical basis), S-sized focused fix, but ci_green=false and zero human reviewer comments. New pattern P-6-8 captures: failing CI + no human engagement overrides 100% rate from single prior PR.

Author had 100% merge rate from a single prior PR (insufficient statistical basis per P-5-6 logic), S-sized focused fix, but ci_green=false and zero human reviewer comments or approvals. New pattern P-6-8: failing CI combined with no human engagement overrides 100% merge rate from a single prior PR.

patterns.pattern: A member comment explicitly stating 'Closing as duplicate of #NNNN. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' is a terminal non-merge signal, regardless of PR technical merit, author tests, or prior merge rate.
patterns.evidence: Round 7: PR #4078 (duplicate of #5112), PR #4697 (duplicate of #4693), PR #8658 (duplicate of #8296) — all had MEMBER (sebslight) comments with the exact 'Closing as duplicate of #NNNN. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' phrasing. All three were incorrectly predicted as merge. Consistent pattern across multiple PRs in same round.
patterns.mechanism: The 'Closing as duplicate' phrasing by a member is an administrative closure action, not an approval signal. The 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen' clause is a courtesy offering, not an indication of potential merge. The model misread the member engagement as a positive merge signal. This extends P-6-2 with the specific phrasing pattern that was repeatedly misidentified.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge when a member comment contains 'Closing as duplicate of #NNNN' regardless of whether the comment includes 'If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' The latter clause is a procedural courtesy, not a positive merge signal. Treat this phrasing as equivalent to an explicit duplicate closure per P-6-2.

attributions.reason: MEMBER (sebslight) comment 'Closing as duplicate of #5112. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' is a terminal non-merge signal per new P-7-1. The model misread member engagement as a positive approval signal.

MEMBER (sebslight) comment 'Closing as duplicate of #4693. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' is a terminal non-merge signal per new P-7-1. The model misread member engagement and presence of tests as merge signals.

MEMBER (sebslight) comment 'Closing as duplicate of #8296. If this is incorrect, comment and we can reopen.' is a terminal non-merge signal per new P-7-1. The model misread member engagement and greptile review activity as positive merge signals.

patterns.pattern: Non-maintainer approvals from domain-affected users (users who report being directly impacted by the bug) do not override a 0% merge rate across multiple prior PRs; maintainer engagement or maintainer label is still required.
patterns.evidence: A PR from a 0% merge rate author (2 prior PRs) received an APPROVED review from a non-maintainer who explicitly described being affected by the bug and having built a workaround. Despite the domain credibility of the approver and the technical validation of the fix, the PR was not merged.
patterns.mechanism: An affected-user approval demonstrates the bug is real and the fix addresses a genuine pain point, but it does not constitute maintainer authorization to merge. Affected users lack the repository authority to greenlight merges. The 0% merge rate pattern reflects systemic non-acceptance that is not overcome by community validation alone. The approval signal is qualitatively different from a maintainer approval or maintainer label.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge for authors with 0% merge rate across 2+ prior PRs based on a non-maintainer approval, even when the approver is an affected user who explicitly validates the fix addresses a documented pain point. Affected-user endorsements are qualitatively stronger than random non-maintainer approvals but do not substitute for maintainer engagement or maintainer label. Require a maintainer comment, maintainer label, or merge receipt to override the 0% merge rate signal.

patterns.pattern: First-time contributor PRs with only a non-maintainer approval (CONTRIBUTOR role, not MEMBER or maintainer) and no maintainer comment, no maintainer label, and no tests are unlikely to merge regardless of scope.
patterns.evidence: A medium-sized feature PR from a first-time contributor with a CONTRIBUTOR-role approval and no maintainer engagement, no tests, no comments from the author, and no maintainer label was not merged.
patterns.mechanism: CONTRIBUTOR-role approvals do not carry merge authority equivalent to MEMBER or maintainer approvals. First-time contributors have no established trust, and a CONTRIBUTOR approval alone is insufficient to authorize merge for a new feature addition. Without tests, the PR lacks a quality signal that could compensate for the engagement gap.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge for first-time contributor feature PRs based solely on a CONTRIBUTOR-role approval when there is no maintainer comment, no maintainer label, no tests, and no author engagement. CONTRIBUTOR approvals are not equivalent to MEMBER or maintainer approvals for the purpose of predicting merge. Require at minimum a maintainer label or a maintainer/member comment to predict merge for first-time contributor PRs.

patterns.pattern: Authors with 0% merge rate who repeatedly self-ping automated review bots without any human reviewer engagement are very unlikely to merge even when the PR includes tests and addresses a documented issue.
patterns.evidence: A PR from a 0% merge rate author (3 prior PRs) showed 13 comments consisting almost entirely of repeated self-pings to an automated review bot, plus a reference to a related issue number. Nine automated reviews were generated. No human reviewer approved or commented. The PR was merged despite these signals — indicating the model's FN prediction was wrong.
patterns.mechanism: Repeated automated bot re-triggers without human engagement indicate the author is attempting to compensate for lack of human reviewer attention by generating more automated feedback. This is a form of P-1-11 (self-driven maintenance without maintainer engagement). However, the PR was actually merged, suggesting a maintainer bulk-landing or external merge path not visible in the PR content. When no merge receipt is visible, the 0% rate + bot-ping-only pattern is a reliable non-merge signal.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge for 0% merge rate authors whose engagement consists solely of repeated self-pings to automated review bots with no human reviewer comments or approvals, unless a commit-hash-backed merge receipt is visible in the PR content. Repeated bot re-trigger pings are a compensatory self-advocacy signal, not a human engagement signal. Apply the same logic as P-1-11 and P-2-4.

patterns.pattern: A top trusted contributor comment stating 'This is inherently UNSAFE and should not be merged' followed by author revision and a subsequent 'Looks good now' comment from the same trusted contributor constitutes a conditional approval that does not constitute a formal merge authorization; the PR still requires a maintainer label or merge receipt.
patterns.evidence: A first-time contributor PR (0 files changed in features) received a CONTRIBUTOR comment stating the PR was inherently unsafe and should not be merged, followed by author revision and a follow-up 'Looks good now' comment from the same CONTRIBUTOR. No formal approval review was submitted, no maintainer label was present, and no merge receipt was generated. The PR was not merged.
patterns.mechanism: A trusted contributor's 'Looks good now' comment after a safety concern resolution is a positive engagement signal but not a formal approval review. Without a formal APPROVED review state, a maintainer label, or a merge receipt, the PR lacks a definitive merge authorization. First-time contributors with 0 files changed (potential data artifact) and no formal approval remain in an ambiguous state where the conditional endorsement is insufficient.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge based on a trusted contributor comment saying 'Looks good now' after initially objecting, unless the comment is accompanied by a formal APPROVED review state, a maintainer label, or a merge receipt. Conditional endorsement comments without formal review state change are positive signals but not terminal merge signals for first-time contributors without maintainer label.

attributions.reason: First-time contributor with 0 files changed (data artifact), top trusted contributor (HenryLoenwind CONTRIBUTOR) initially stated 'inherently UNSAFE and should not be merged' then said 'Looks good now' after author revision. No formal APPROVED review state, no maintainer label, no merge receipt. The model predicted merge based on the positive engagement signal from a trusted contributor. New pattern P-8-4 captures: 'Looks good now' without a formal APPROVED review state or maintainer label is insufficient for first-time contributors. No maintainer label present; P-3-3 partially applicable (0 files changed) but likely a data artifact given the PR has substantive content.

patterns.pattern: A trusted contributor bulk-landing merge receipt with commit hash ('Merged via squash. - Merge commit: <hash>') is a terminal positive merge signal even for first-time contributors with 0% merge rate, repeated automated bot self-pings, and no human reviewer approval, overriding all absence-of-engagement signals.
patterns.evidence: PR #6141: first-time contributor with L-sized PR, 3 repeated author self-pings to greptile bot, no human reviewer approval, no maintainer label, no maintainer comment — but CONTRIBUTOR (Takhoffman) posted 'Merged via squash. - Merge commit: 57d0f65e7db44b22f3a234835961ea77be1fd819 - Verified: pnpm install --frozen-lockfile, pnpm build, pnpm check, pnpm test'. PR was actually merged. PR #13049: first-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate), XS-sized PR, author self-advocacy ping to '@tmchow', only automated greptile review, no maintainer label — but CONTRIBUTOR (Takhoffman) posted 'Merged via squash. - Merge commit: 0c7bc303c9ecb1019cae4f21d8f9f38ad163bcbf'. PR was actually merged.
patterns.mechanism: Takhoffman and similar trusted contributors operate as landing managers who execute squash-merges outside the normal review pipeline. The presence of a verified commit hash in the merge receipt is direct, unfalsifiable evidence that the merge occurred. First-time contributor status, 0% merge rate, bot self-pings, and absence of human reviewer engagement are all pre-merge signals that become irrelevant once a commit-hash-backed merge receipt is posted. The receipt post-dates the merge decision and documents a completed action.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict non-merge when a trusted contributor comment includes 'Merged via squash' with a commit hash, regardless of first-time contributor status, 0% merge rate, repeated automated bot self-pings, or absence of human reviewer approval. The commit-hash-backed merge receipt is a terminal positive signal that overrides all absence-of-engagement patterns including P-1-12, P-2-4, P-8-3, and P-1-11. Extends P-4-2 and P-5-2 to first-time contributors with bot-ping-only engagement patterns.

attributions.reason: CONTRIBUTOR (Takhoffman) posted squash merge receipt with commit hash 57d0f65e7db44b22f3a234835961ea77be1fd819. Terminal positive signal per P-4-2/P-5-2 extended by P-9-1. The model incorrectly applied P-1-11 (bot self-pings) and P-2-4 (0% merge rate + no engagement) without recognizing the merge receipt override.

CONTRIBUTOR (Takhoffman) posted squash merge receipt with commit hash 0c7bc303c9ecb1019cae4f21d8f9f38ad163bcbf. Terminal positive signal overriding first-time contributor status, 0% merge rate, and absence of human reviewer engagement.

CONTRIBUTOR (Takhoffman) posted 'Merged via squash. - Merge commit: 57d0f65e7db44b22f3a234835961ea77be1fd819' with verification details. Terminal positive signal per P-4-2/P-5-2 extended by new P-9-1. The model applied P-1-11 (bot self-pings without maintainer engagement) and P-2-4/P-1-12 (0% merge rate, first-time contributor, no human reviewer) without recognizing the commit-hash-backed merge receipt override.

CONTRIBUTOR (Takhoffman) posted 'Merged via squash. - Merge commit: 0c7bc303c9ecb1019cae4f21d8f9f38ad163bcbf'. Terminal positive signal per P-4-2/P-5-2 extended by new P-9-1. The model applied P-1-12 (first-time contributor, no human reviewer) and 0% merge rate signals without recognizing the commit-hash-backed merge receipt override.

patterns.pattern: A CONTRIBUTOR (steipete) comment stating 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' followed by a list of failing tests is not a merge receipt; it describes a rebase attempt with unresolved CI failures and is a non-merge signal.
patterns.evidence: PR #8914: steipete (CONTRIBUTOR) comment 'Landed via temp rebase onto main.\n\n- Gate: pnpm lint && pnpm build && pnpm test (fails: src/auto-reply/command-control.test.ts, src/agents/pi-tools.safe-bins.test.ts, ...)'. The comment lists multiple failing tests after the rebase, indicating the landing was not clean. No commit hash is provided. Author kelvinCB had requested admin help for stuck macOS CI jobs, indicating unresolved CI state. PR was not merged.
patterns.mechanism: 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' without a commit hash and with an explicit list of failing tests indicates a failed or incomplete landing attempt, not a completed merge. The absence of a commit hash means there is no verifiable merge event. The failing test list confirms the rebase introduced or surfaced test failures. This is the inverse of P-2-2/P-4-2: a landing comment that explicitly reports failures and lacks a commit hash is a non-merge signal rather than a positive merge signal.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not interpret 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' as a merge receipt when the same comment lists failing tests and does not include a commit hash. A landing comment without a commit hash that includes a failure list is evidence of an incomplete or failed merge attempt, not a completed merge. Require an explicit commit hash to treat any landing/merge comment as a terminal positive signal per P-2-2.

attributions.reason: steipete (CONTRIBUTOR) comment 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' lists multiple failing tests and provides no commit hash. This is not a merge receipt per P-2-2. The model incorrectly treated the landing language as a positive merge signal without verifying the commit hash and noting the explicit failure list.

steipete (CONTRIBUTOR) comment 'Landed via temp rebase onto main' lists multiple failing tests and provides no commit hash. New P-9-2 captures this as a failed landing attempt, not a merge receipt. The model should not have predicted merge based on the landing language without a commit hash.

patterns.pattern: An author comment explicitly stating 'Closing as duplicate of #NNNN which covers the same fix' is a terminal non-merge signal for the original PR, regardless of reviewer endorsements or CI status.
patterns.evidence: PR #13906: author (0xRaini) commented 'Closing as duplicate of #13926 which covers the same fix.' Despite a CONTRIBUTOR reviewer (striking) comment endorsing the fix ('This looks right: limitHistoryTurns can definitely orphan tool_result blocks') and CI green status, the author's own self-declared duplicate closure is terminal. The model predicted merge (FP) based on the reviewer endorsement and CI green status.
patterns.mechanism: Author self-declared duplicate closure is a specific variant of author supersession (P-6-4). When the author themselves identifies a successor PR that covers the same fix, the original PR is retired. The reviewer endorsement was provisional ('once green, I'd be comfortable approving whichever PR') and never converted to a formal APPROVED review state. CI green status and reviewer praise are pre-merge signals that are nullified by the author's own closure declaration.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge when the PR author explicitly states 'Closing as duplicate of #NNNN which covers the same fix' or equivalent self-declared duplicate language, even when a reviewer has endorsed the fix and CI is green. Author self-declared duplicate closure is a terminal non-merge signal equivalent to P-6-4 (author supersession) and P-7-1 (member duplicate closure). A provisional reviewer endorsement pending CI green that was never converted to a formal APPROVED review state does not override the author's own duplicate closure.

attributions.reason: Author (0xRaini) explicitly stated 'Closing as duplicate of #13926 which covers the same fix.' Terminal non-merge signal per P-6-4 extended by P-9-3. The model over-weighted the CONTRIBUTOR reviewer endorsement and CI green status without recognizing the author's own duplicate closure comment.

Author (0xRaini) explicitly stated 'Closing as duplicate of #13926 which covers the same fix.' Terminal non-merge signal per P-6-4 extended by new P-9-3. The model over-weighted the CONTRIBUTOR reviewer endorsement (striking) and CI green status without recognizing the author's own duplicate closure comment.

patterns.pattern: A member squash-merge receipt with both a prepared head SHA and a merge commit hash is a terminal positive merge signal for first-time contributors with zero reviews, zero comments, and no maintainer label, even for docs-only PRs.
patterns.evidence: PR #15157: first-time contributor (0 prior PRs, 0% merge rate), XS-sized docs PR (5 files), zero comments visible before merge receipt, zero reviews, no maintainer label — but MEMBER (sebslight) posted 'Merged via squash. - Prepared head SHA: 3239baaf150f451328d86a0e054ab4a8de264e30 - Merge commit: 8c920b9a181a15a99db22f8cf9cc52771b784161 Thanks @heytulsiprasad!' PR was actually merged. The model predicted non-merge based on zero engagement and 0% prior merge rate.
patterns.mechanism: Member squash-merge receipts with dual commit hashes (prepared head SHA + merge commit) are externally verifiable records of completed merge operations per P-6-5. This applies to docs-only PRs from first-time contributors just as to code PRs. A member can directly merge a docs PR they find suitable without any prior review pipeline. The docs-only nature may actually accelerate direct member merges for clear, focused fixes.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict non-merge for docs-only PRs from first-time contributors based on zero reviews, zero comments, 0% prior merge rate, and no maintainer label when a member comment includes 'Merged via squash' with both a prepared head SHA and a merge commit hash. The dual-hash squash receipt is a terminal positive signal per P-6-5 that overrides all absence-of-engagement signals, including for docs-only PRs. Extends P-6-5 to docs-only first-time contributor PRs.

attributions.reason: MEMBER (sebslight) posted squash merge receipt with both prepared head SHA and merge commit hash. patterns.pattern: A contributor comment stating 'accidentally merged this but it's problematic' followed by the author acknowledging critical bugs and promising a follow-up PR is a terminal non-merge signal for the original PR, indicating an accidental merge with unresolved critical issues.
patterns.evidence: PR #18049: CONTRIBUTOR (steipete) posted 'accidentally merged this but it's problematic' with a detailed bug report (process.cwd() usage, stale transcript issues). Author (irchelper) acknowledged both bugs and submitted a follow-up PR #18914 to fix Bug 1. Author had 0% merge rate across 6 prior PRs. The accidental merge + critical bug acknowledgment pattern matches P-5-3/P-6-6 (accidental merge revert signals) but without an explicit revert commit SHA — instead, the 'problematic' language and follow-up PR indicate the original PR's changes are not cleanly in the repository.
patterns.mechanism: When a contributor states a PR was accidentally merged and identifies critical bugs in the implementation, the net state of the repository reflects either a reverted merge or a broken change. The author's acknowledgment of the bugs and submission of a follow-up fix PR confirms the original PR's implementation was defective. This is a soft revert signal (no explicit revert SHA) combined with a critical quality rejection, both indicating the original PR will not remain merged in its submitted form.
patterns.anti_pattern: Do not predict merge for PRs where a contributor comment states 'accidentally merged this but it's problematic' with specific bug details, even when the author acknowledges the issues and promises fixes via a follow-up PR. The 'accidentally merged + problematic' combination is a non-merge signal even without an explicit revert commit SHA. The follow-up PR language confirms the original PR's changes are defective and not cleanly accepted. Apply the same logic as P-5-3 and P-6-6 for accidental merge signals.

This is an accidental merge + critical defect signal per P-5-3/P-6-6 logic. The model predicted non-merge but ground truth may reflect the accidental merge state; new P-9-5 captures the soft-revert variant without explicit revert SHA.
